awd_titl_txt: IRES: US-UK: Enabling Ultra-Dense Future Cellular Networks (5G)
awd_abstract_narration:
This IRES project at The University of Oklahoma will support international research experiences for US engineering students to work at the globally recognized 5th Generation Cellular Systems Innovation Centre (5GIC) at the University of Surrey, U.K. In each of its three years, the twelve-week program supported by this project will provide five (2 graduate, and 3 undergraduate) students an opportunity to work closely with an internationally renowned research group in three focused research areas within the domain of next generation ultra-dense wireless cellular networks namely: Interference Mitigation, Energy Efficiency and Mobility Management. This project will also provide participants an opportunity for a hands on research experience using a one of a kind, outdoor, large scale 5G test-bed for wireless cellular system innovation that has recently been established at the University of Surrey as part of 5GIC.  Ultra-dense deployment of cellular systems is inevitable in near future to meet mounting capacity demands. Interference, energy and mobility are emerging as key constrains in realization of ultra-dense networks. This project focuses on building complementary international cooperative efforts to address these challenges. 

This project will enable US students and PIs to establish long-term collaborative links with globally recognized academia and international industrial partners in cellular domain. The project will introduce students to the European perspective on research and development in cellular domain. The extensive field research experiences planned in this project for undergraduates will help to increase the success of these students in graduate programs in engineering fields. For the graduate students participants, the opportunity to do validation of their ideas on a real network (5G test-bed) will help to transform and enhance their understanding of their research and promote the ability of US engineers to advance and contribute to leadership on state of the art mobile broadband wireless networks.
org_div_long_name: Office of International Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit Outcome of The Project

In terms of intellectual merit, the project has resulted in twelve journal publications and six conference publications on the topic of 5G and beyond. These publications were co-authored by the IRES participants as well international collaborators. Below are select examples of key contributions made by the project.

 

  • A framework for spatio-temporal characterization of user traffic was developed using real CDR dataset. The distribution of multi-faceted cellular traffic while identifying the factors and latent features influencing the parameterization of the distribution was characterized. This characterization is the first step in designing, optimizing and automating a mobile cellular network.
  • Solutions for enhanced MDT-based performance estimation in cellular networks are developed. These solutions include the optimization of bin width for a given area, user density and user positioning error, that will minimize the overall error in coverage estimation. A framework to calibrate the observed coverage in order to estimate the true coverage in various network scenarios is also developed.
  • A stochastic geometry-based framework to analyze the SINR outage probability in the uplink of multitier mmWave cellular networks with truncation channel inversion power control is developed. The framework incorporates the effect of blockages, the per-user power control as well as maximum power limitations of the users.
  • One of the 2019 IRES participants successfully completed her experimental data gathering campaign at 5GIC Testbed, Surrey, UK. The data gathered in this campaign is has enabled a new level of cross validation of the theoretical and simulation-based results produced in the lab. 
  • A machine learning based solution consisting of convolutional neural network and random forest to detect fault symptoms and identify their cause using received signal strength measurements was developed.
  • A machine learning based framework for KPI maximization in emerging networks using mobility parameters was proposed. In this framework, optimal combination of two pertinent configuration and optimization parameters used in mobility, Cell Individual Offset (CIO) and Handover Margin (HOM) was discovered, that maximizes a specific key performance indicator such as mean Signal to Interference and Noise Ratio (SINR) of all the connected users.
  • A realistic evaluation of AI-assisted mobility predictors for HetNets is performed. Mobility prediction was modeled as a multi-class classification problem to predict the future base station association of the mobile users using machine learning techniques. The data used for this evaluation framework was from a 3GPP-compliant cellular network simulator, that was built by PI’s team, comprising of IRES participants as well.
  • Another mobility management-based outcome was the comparison analysis of four different machine learning-based mobility predictors/models. The effectiveness of each model was evaluated not only based on the model’s ability to predict the future location of mobile users but also the time each algorithm takes to be fully trained and perform such prediction.
  • An artificial intelligence empowered self-organizing network (SON) solution to optimally distribute users among relays and macro cells in an automated way such that holistic network performance is optimized was developed. Contrary to existing studies, this work presents a novel idea of traffic service class-based cell individual offset (SCIO) to further enhance the gains achieved from deployment of relay nodes.

 

 

Broader Impact Outcomes of the Project

The project has given diverse and rich international research and collaboration experience to over a dozen young USA undergrad and graduate students. Benefitting from this experience and resultant publications they co-authored, the project  participants have secured PhD scholarships at national and international institutes or jobs with top employers in the country. For example, one female graduate of the project with Hispanic background secured PhD scholarship at Queens Mary University London, UK. Other female graduate of the project has won several awards including dissertation excellence award at OU. An African American undergraduate female student’s work has resulted in peer review conference publication. One of the project graduates has joined Amazon as national program lead for their training programs.  In terms of broader impact on technology advancement, project has resulted in several technical contributions, some of which are identified above, that are set to shape future standard for cellular network.  These contributions have been disseminated not only in terms of peer reviewed publications but also through a total of fifteen invited talks, keynotes and tutorials by PIs at international industry forums, conferences and industry campuses.

In this backdrop, it is safe to conclude that project has met all its goals and exceeded its expected outcomes in several expects. 

 


Last Modified: 11/12/2021
Modified by: Ali Imran

Intellectual Merit Outcome of The Project

In terms of intellectual merit, the project has resulted in twelve journal publications and six conference publications on the topic of 5G and beyond. These publications were co-authored by the IRES participants as well international collaborators. Below are select examples of key contributions made by the project.

 

A framework for spatio-temporal characterization of user traffic was developed using real CDR dataset. The distribution of multi-faceted cellular traffic while identifying the factors and latent features influencing the parameterization of the distribution was characterized. This characterization is the first step in designing, optimizing and automating a mobile cellular network.
Solutions for enhanced MDT-based performance estimation in cellular networks are developed. These solutions include the optimization of bin width for a given area, user density and user positioning error, that will minimize the overall error in coverage estimation. A framework to calibrate the observed coverage in order to estimate the true coverage in various network scenarios is also developed.
A stochastic geometry-based framework to analyze the SINR outage probability in the uplink of multitier mmWave cellular networks with truncation channel inversion power control is developed. The framework incorporates the effect of blockages, the per-user power control as well as maximum power limitations of the users.
One of the 2019 IRES participants successfully completed her experimental data gathering campaign at 5GIC Testbed, Surrey, UK. The data gathered in this campaign is has enabled a new level of cross validation of the theoretical and simulation-based results produced in the lab. 
A machine learning based solution consisting of convolutional neural network and random forest to detect fault symptoms and identify their cause using received signal strength measurements was developed.
A machine learning based framework for KPI maximization in emerging networks using mobility parameters was proposed. In this framework, optimal combination of two pertinent configuration and optimization parameters used in mobility, Cell Individual Offset (CIO) and Handover Margin (HOM) was discovered, that maximizes a specific key performance indicator such as mean Signal to Interference and Noise Ratio (SINR) of all the connected users.
A realistic evaluation of AI-assisted mobility predictors for HetNets is performed. Mobility prediction was modeled as a multi-class classification problem to predict the future base station association of the mobile users using machine learning techniques. The data used for this evaluation framework was from a 3GPP-compliant cellular network simulator, that was built by PI’s team, comprising of IRES participants as well.
Another mobility management-based outcome was the comparison analysis of four different machine learning-based mobility predictors/models. The effectiveness of each model was evaluated not only based on the model’s ability to predict the future location of mobile users but also the time each algorithm takes to be fully trained and perform such prediction.
An artificial intelligence empowered self-organizing network (SON) solution to optimally distribute users among relays and macro cells in an automated way such that holistic network performance is optimized was developed. Contrary to existing studies, this work presents a novel idea of traffic service class-based cell individual offset (SCIO) to further enhance the gains achieved from deployment of relay nodes.


 

 

Broader Impact Outcomes of the Project

The project has given diverse and rich international research and collaboration experience to over a dozen young USA undergrad and graduate students. Benefitting from this experience and resultant publications they co-authored, the project  participants have secured PhD scholarships at national and international institutes or jobs with top employers in the country. For example, one female graduate of the project with Hispanic background secured PhD scholarship at Queens Mary University London, UK. Other female graduate of the project has won several awards including dissertation excellence award at OU. An African American undergraduate female student’s work has resulted in peer review conference publication. One of the project graduates has joined Amazon as national program lead for their training programs.  In terms of broader impact on technology advancement, project has resulted in several technical contributions, some of which are identified above, that are set to shape future standard for cellular network.  These contributions have been disseminated not only in terms of peer reviewed publications but also through a total of fifteen invited talks, keynotes and tutorials by PIs at international industry forums, conferences and industry campuses.

In this backdrop, it is safe to conclude that project has met all its goals and exceeded its expected outcomes in several expects.
